This is Talk of the Nation.
Goodbye, Slim Pickens.

I'm Neal Conan in Washington.

After almost a quarter century as a Middle East specialist in the State Department, Aaron David Miller asked a pointed question in a new book: Why has the world's greatest super power failed to broker or impose a solution in the Middle East?
He concludes that at least part of the problem is that small powers in the region are much more deeply invested than the distant super power.
Quote, ""sometimes, we succeed,"" he writes.
But more often than not, we are distracted, hoodwinked, sidetracked or just plain screwed by small powers who want to befriend and use us at the same time.

Aaron David Miller believes that both peace is possible, and that the United States has an essential role, not, he says, because it's neutral, but precisely because of its unwavering support of Israel.
He also argues that the next president would be well advised to take a position that better reflects Arab and Palestinian views.
What is the U.S.
interest in the Middle East?
Why is it important to try to broker agreements when conditions seem so unpromising and so many factions unwilling to take risks?
E-mail us: talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later in the hour, hundreds of flights are grounded for safety inspections right in the middle of a busy spring vacation season.
If you're worried about how safe your plane is, you can ask the experts a little later.
But first, Aaron David Miller joins us here on Studio 3A.
His new book is called ""The Much Too Promised Land: America's Elusive Search for Arab-Israeli Peace."" Nice to have you back on TALK OF THE NATION.
It's a pleasure to be here.
And part of the book is advice to the next president, as I mentioned.
Obviously, the current president has several months left in office, and says he believes there's plenty of time to reach an agreement before he leaves.
Do you think he's right?
I think it's possible.
I mean, the reality is that the most important thing to come out of the Annapolis process is not a more robust American role.
In fact, we're still on the sidelines.
(As Jim Stark) Mom, a boy--a kid was killed tonight!
I don't see how I can get out of that by pretending that it didn't happen!
None of these Catholic Democratic voters mentions what is generally assumed to be the big issue for Catholics, abortion.
Father Auth says the issue is important to them, but he says that they also look at the war, the death penalty or services for the poor.
As for pro-choice candidates.
If they have voted pro-choice but have an ethic - a consistent ethic of life, we could vote for that.
We wouldn't have a problem.
And even if Catholics don't vote in a bloc, what most do in the primaries may be a sign of their direction in November, especially in a big swing state like Ohio.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, Toledo.
And you can learn more about what's at stake in the upcoming primaries in Ohio and Texas at npr.org/elections.
While foreclosure problems persist, business is booming at the upper end of the housing market.
In fact, luxury properties costing at least $10 million are being snapped up by the super rich.
And as NPR's Carrie Kahn says, California is a hot spot for that, too.
But there's no for-sale sign out front.
In fact, you have to get a credit check before Realtor Joyce Rey will give you a tour.
And the main salon has wonderful high ceilings and beautiful molding details.
Two fireplaces that have never been used.
On the grounds, there's also a stadium tennis court and a 10-car garage with nine bedrooms above.
Those are for the staff.
The original list price was $53 million and it has been reduced to $40 million.
That's so I could get in at 40.
I couldn't do 53.
Rey, a petite platinum blonde dressed in a pale gray suit that matches her Mercedes, isn't worried about the sales price.
This year, 23 estates priced at $10 million or above have sold in the area.
That's double last year's totals.
Rey has been breaking records since the '70s, when she sold a home here for $4.2 million.
So that was hot news all over the country.
They couldn't believe that anybody was going to pay that much money for a house in 1978.
So, you can see how far we've come.
Luxury homes are selling so well these days there's even a room for a niche market - the fully furnished, fully stocked estates, complete with a plasma screen TV in every room.
It's immediate gratification.
That's exactly what it is.
It's for people who appreciate quality and want it now.
San Diego realtor Patricia Kramer sells the move-in specials, some as large as 20,000 square feet in the county's Rancho Santa Fe suburb.
You walk in and you can bring your toothbrush and you are home.
Unidentified Woman: Five bedrooms, eight bathrooms, a home office, wine cellar, home theater, and guest casita spread out-
It's another gilded age in America.
The wealthy are rapidly becoming wealthier.
Rick Goodwin, publisher of Unique Homes magazine, says there are now six U.S.
residents on the market priced at more than $100 million.
Most will be bought by rich people you've never heard of.
At the very high end, it's going to be people with international connections.
In fact, the low dollar has made U.S.
trophy homes a good deal for foreigners.
But Americans aren't far behind, says John Karevoll, with the real- estate information service DataQuick.
The growth in the economy has benefited the very high-end households more than it's benefited middle-income and lower- income households.
In fact, lower-income households are probably doing worse than they were 5, 10, 20 years ago.
According to census data, middle-income families saw their wealth increase a little more than 7 percent in the last 15 years.
Contrast that with the richest 5 percent of the population, who've seen their wealth soar 40 percent.
And now, I'm going to take you upstairs in the private elevator to the main master suite.
That's good news for Realtor Joyce Rey, who specializes in estates in L.A.'s Bel-Air, Beverly Hills and Holmby Hills neighborhoods, known for years as the Golden Triangle.
And now, it's the platinum triangle.
Do you think it needs to get a step up, something higher than platinum now?
Titanium triangle?
I'm not too sure where you go from platinum.
Carrie Kahn, NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Debbie Elliott.
A long and controversial life came to an end today.
Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator of Chile, died at the age of 91 after suffering a heart attack last week.
In 1973, Pinochet led the military coup that overthrew Chile's elected Socialist president, Salvador Allende.
Pinochet remained in power for the next 17 years, but spent his old age fighting charges of human rights abuses.
In a few moments, we'll take an in-depth look at his career.
First, though, we get an update from the Chilean capital, Santiago, on how the news of Pinochet's death was received.
Nathan Crooks is the editor of the Santiago Times.
Hello.
I understand there are now crowds on the streets there.
Yes, crowds have been gathering all day.

They started out as relatively calm, but by midday, thousands of people were in the streets and anti-Pinochet forces congregated mostly around the Plaza Italia - which is in the center of town - while Pinochet supporters gathered outside of the military hospital.
Has there been any violence?
